This work involves planting various locally suitable medicinal herbs, shrubs, or trees to diversify the sources of natural remedies and income for rural households. Workers prepare the land by digging appropriate pits, applying organic fertilizers, and ensuring proper spacing to support the unique growth habits of different healing species. Once these mixed medicinal plantations mature, they provide a steady supply of roots, leaves, and bark for the pharmaceutical and wellness industries, making the local economy more resilient.

This work involves planting shade-giving, fruit-bearing, and ornamental trees within the premises of schools, health centers, and community halls to create a green and healthy environment. Workers focus on digging pits, soil solarization, and installing protective fencing to ensure the saplings survive in high-traffic public areas. Once mature, these plantations provide clean air, cooling shade for students and patients, and a sustainable source of fresh produce for the entire community.

This work involves planting aesthetic and shade-giving trees along both sides of roads, highways, and walkways to create green corridors in rural and semi-urban areas. Workers focus on digging uniform pits, providing sturdy tree guards for protection, and ensuring regular watering to help the saplings withstand dust and vehicle exhaust. Once mature, these plantations reduce soil erosion, lower ambient temperatures, and provide a pleasant, shaded environment for travelers and local residents.

This work involves planting moisture-loving and soil-binding trees along the embankments of primary and secondary canals to stabilize the soil and prevent erosion. Workers focus on digging pits at specific intervals along the slopes and banks, choosing species that can thrive in water-rich environments without damaging the canal structure with aggressive roots. Once mature, these plantations act as natural windbreaks to reduce water evaporation, strengthen the canal banks against breaches during heavy flow, and provide a sustainable source of timber and fodder for the local farming community.

Work Name: Raising of Tea Plantation in Community Wasteland
content: This work involves transforming underutilized community wastelands into productive tea gardens by preparing the soil with organic matter and ensuring proper drainage for the young tea clones. Workers focus on contour planting and creating shade-tree canopies to protect the delicate shrubs from extreme sunlight while maintaining the specific acidity levels required for healthy growth. Once established, these plantations provide a consistent source of green leaf harvest, generating long-term employment and turning barren communal land into a sustainable economic asset for the village.

Work Name: Raising of Coffee Plantation in Community Wasteland
content: This work involves converting idle community wastelands into productive coffee estates by preparing the soil with organic mulch and planting high-quality Arabica or Robusta saplings. Workers focus on establishing silver oak or dadap trees to provide the necessary filtered shade and nitrogen fixation required for the delicate coffee shrubs to thrive. Once mature, these plantations provide a sustainable harvest of coffee cherries, creating long-term seasonal employment and a robust revenue stream for the local community.

Work Name: Raising of Other Plantation in Community Wasteland
content: This work involves transforming degraded or idle communal lands into productive green zones by planting a mix of locally hardy fruit, timber, or fodder trees suited to the specific soil conditions. Workers focus on clearing invasive weeds, digging staggered trenches for water conservation, and installing sturdy protection to ensure high survival rates for the saplings. Once established, these multi-purpose plantations restore soil fertility, prevent encroachment, and provide a diverse range of forest produce and seasonal income for the entire village community.

Work Name: Raising of Plantation in Forest Area
content: This work involves the systematic planting of indigenous tree species within degraded forest patches to restore the natural canopy and enhance local biodiversity. Workers focus on site clearance of invasive weeds, digging pits following the natural contour of the land, and planting nursery-raised saplings that match the original forest type. Once established, these plantations prevent soil erosion, recharge groundwater levels, and provide a critical habitat for wildlife while ensuring a sustainable supply of non-timber forest produce for nearby communities.

This work involves planting high-yielding Mulberry varieties in well-prepared, nutrient-rich soil to establish a dedicated fodder base for silkworm rearing. Workers focus on close-row spacing and regular pruning to encourage the growth of lush, protein-rich green foliage essential for high-quality cocoon production. Once established, these plantations support multiple silkworm crops per year, providing a steady and lucrative source of income for rural households through the sale of raw silk cocoons.

Work Name: Raising of Jatropha Tree Borne Oil Seed Plantation
content: This work involves planting hardy Jatropha saplings in well-drained, marginal rural lands to establish a sustainable source of non-edible oilseeds for biofuel production. Workers focus on digging appropriately spaced pits and applying organic manure to ensure the drought-resistant shrubs develop strong root systems even in poor soil conditions. Once mature, the plantation yields oil-rich seeds that can be processed into biodiesel, providing a renewable energy source and a consistent income stream for local farmers.

Work Name: Raising of Karanj Tree Borne Oil Seed Plantation
content: This work involves planting hardy Karanj (Pongamia) saplings in degraded or marginal rural lands to establish a permanent source of non-edible oilseeds for biofuel and medicinal use. Workers focus on digging deep pits and providing initial protection to help these nitrogen-fixing trees develop strong root systems that can withstand both drought and waterlogging. Once mature, the plantation yields oil-rich seeds and nitrogen-rich green manure, providing a sustainable income stream through the biofuel industry while significantly improving soil fertility for the local community.

Work Name: Raising of Wild Apricot Tree Borne Oil Seed Plantation
content: This work involves planting hardy Wild Apricot (Chuli) saplings in high-altitude or temperate rural lands to establish a permanent source of oil-rich kernels for culinary and medicinal use. Workers focus on digging deep pits on sloped terrains and providing initial winter protection to help these frost-tolerant trees develop the deep root systems needed for long-term stability. Once mature, the plantation yields bitter kernels that are processed into high-value oils and scrubs, providing a resilient and lucrative income source for mountainous communities.

Work Name: Raising of Simaoubha Tree Borne Oil Seed Plantation
content: This work involves planting hardy Simarouba (Laxmitaru) saplings in well-drained rural lands to establish a permanent source of high-quality non-edible oilseeds for biofuel and medicinal use. Workers focus on digging deep pits and providing initial protection to help these drought-tolerant, evergreen trees develop the extensive root systems required to thrive in marginal soils. Once mature, the plantation yields oil-rich seeds and medicinal leaves, providing a versatile and sustainable income stream while significantly contributing to the greening of degraded landscapes.

Work Name: Raising of Mohua Tree Borne Oil Seed Plantation
content: This work involves planting hardy Mahua (Madhuca longifolia) saplings in well-drained rural lands to establish a permanent source of oil-rich seeds and succulent flowers. Workers focus on digging deep pits and providing initial protection to help these long-lived, multi-purpose trees develop the massive root systems needed to thrive in tropical climates. Once mature, the plantation provides a steady supply of seeds for oil extraction and flowers for food and traditional beverages, offering a robust and culturally significant income source for tribal and rural communities.

Work Name: Raising of Kokum Tree Borne Oil Seed Plantation
content: This work involves planting hardy Kokum (Garcinia indica) saplings in well-drained, high-rainfall rural lands to establish a permanent source of oil-rich seeds and medicinal fruits. Workers focus on digging deep pits and providing initial shade protection to help these evergreen, forest-dwelling trees develop the strong root systems required for long-term productivity. Once mature, the plantation yields seeds processed into high-value Kokum butter and rinds used in traditional health tonics, offering a lucrative and sustainable income stream for coastal and hilly communities.

Work Name: Raising of Jojoba Tree Borne Oil Seed Plantation
content: This work involves planting hardy Jojoba saplings in well-drained, arid, or semi-arid rural lands to establish a permanent source of high-value liquid wax seeds. Workers focus on digging appropriately spaced pits and ensuring a specific ratio of male to female plants to facilitate wind pollination for maximum seed yield. Once mature, the plantation provides a sustainable supply of seeds used in premium cosmetics and industrial lubricants, offering a drought-resilient and highly profitable income stream for farmers in dryland regions.

Work Name: Raising of Neem Tree Borne Oil Seed Plantation
content: This work involves planting hardy Neem (Azadirachta indica) saplings in well-drained rural or marginal lands to establish a permanent source of oil-rich seeds and medicinal leaves. Workers focus on digging deep pits and providing initial protection to help these drought-resistant, evergreen trees develop the robust root systems needed for long-term survival in various soil types. Once mature, the plantation yields seeds used for high-value organic pesticides and fertilizers, providing a sustainable and eco-friendly income stream for the local community.

Work Name: Raising of Anjeer Tree Borne Oil Seed Plantation
content: This work involves planting high-yielding Anjeer (Fig) saplings in well-drained, loamy soil to establish a permanent source of nutrient-dense fruits and oil-rich seeds. Workers focus on digging wide pits and ensuring proper spacing to allow for the spreading canopy and deep root systems characteristic of these hardy trees. Once mature, the plantation provides a steady supply of fruits for drying and seeds for high-value oil extraction, offering a lucrative and sustainable income stream for rural farming communities.

Work Name: Raising of Cheura Tree Borne Oil Seed Plantation
content: This work involves planting hardy Cheura (Indian Butter Tree) saplings in hilly or sub-Himalayan rural lands to establish a permanent source of high-value vegetable butter and oilseeds. Workers focus on digging deep pits on sloped terrains and providing initial protection to help these frost-tolerant, evergreen trees develop the extensive root systems required for long-term productivity. Once mature, the plantation yields seeds processed into Cheura Ghee for culinary and cosmetic use, providing a resilient and lucrative income source for mountainous communities.

Work Name: Raising of Tung Tree Borne Oil Seed Plantation
content: This work involves planting high-yielding Tung (Vernicia fordii) saplings in well-drained, acidic soil to establish a permanent source of high-quality industrial oilseeds. Workers focus on digging appropriately spaced pits on hilly or undulating terrain and ensuring proper mulching to support the rapid growth of these deciduous, frost-tolerant trees. Once mature, the plantation yields seeds processed into premium quick-drying oil used for wood finishing and varnishes, providing a specialized and lucrative income stream for rural communities.

Work Name: Raising of Olive Tree Borne Oil Seed Plantation
content: This work involves planting high-quality Olive saplings in well-drained, lime-rich soils to establish a permanent source of premium oil-bearing drupes. Workers focus on digging appropriately spaced pits and implementing precise pruning techniques to ensure maximum sunlight penetration and airflow within the silvery-green canopy. Once mature, the plantation yields oil-rich fruits processed into high-value culinary and medicinal oils, providing a drought-resilient and prestigious income stream for communities in Mediterranean-style climates.

Work Name: Raising of Oil Palm Tree Borne Oil Seed Plantation
content: This work involves planting high-yielding Oil Palm (Elaeis guineensis) saplings in fertile, well-irrigated rural lands to establish a permanent source of oil-rich fresh fruit bunches. Workers focus on digging large, staggered pits and implementing precise drip irrigation systems to support the high water and nutrient requirements of these tropical palms. Once mature, the plantation yields fruit clusters processed into high-value palm oil and palm kernel oil, providing a highly productive and continuous income stream for local farming communities.

Work Name: Raising of Other Tree Borne Oil Seed Plantation
content: This work involves planting a variety of diverse, non-traditional oil-bearing tree species in marginal or community lands to establish a resilient source of non-edible oils and industrial raw materials. Workers focus on selecting site-specific species such as Salvadora (Pilu) or Kusum that can thrive in challenging soil conditions while providing high oil yields from their seeds. Once mature, these plantations provide a sustainable supply of seeds for soap, lubricant, and medicinal industries, ensuring a steady income stream and long-term ecological restoration for rural communities.

Work Name: Construction of Roof Top Rain Water Harvesting Structure
content: This work involves installing a system of PVC gutters, downpipes, and filtration units on building rooftops to capture and divert clean rainwater into dedicated storage tanks or underground recharge pits. Workers focus on ensuring proper slope alignment and the installation of a first-flush diverter to prevent debris and initial runoff contaminants from entering the main storage. Once functional, the structure provides a self-sustaining source of soft water for domestic use or groundwater replenishment, significantly reducing dependence on external water tankers and municipal supplies.

Work Name: Repair & Maintenance of Roof Top Rain Water Harvesting Structure
content: This work involves installing a system of PVC gutters, downpipes, and filtration units on building rooftops to capture and divert clean rainwater into dedicated storage tanks or underground recharge pits. Thematic Domain: Domain II: Core Rural Infrastructure (Rural Amenities)
content: This work involves constructing specialized conduits such as culverts, hume pipes, or inverted siphons to allow the safe passage of natural drainage water across an artificial canal or roadway. Workers focus on excavating precise foundations and reinforced concrete wing walls to prevent soil erosion and ensure the structural integrity of the crossing point during peak monsoon flows. Once completed, the structure prevents waterlogging and protects vital infrastructure from damage, ensuring the uninterrupted flow of both irrigation water and local transport.

content: This work involves constructing reinforced concrete pipes or box-like structures beneath roads or embankments to allow the controlled passage of water from one side to the other. Workers focus on excavating stable foundations and installing sturdy headwalls to prevent soil erosion and ensure the structural integrity of the overhead path during heavy rainfall. Once completed, the culvert prevents water accumulation and road washouts, providing a critical drainage solution that maintains local transport connectivity and soil stability.

Thematic Domain: Domain II: Core Rural Infrastructure (Rural Amenities)
Work Name: Construction of Rural Foot Over Bridge
content: This work involves constructing elevated pedestrian walkways using reinforced concrete, steel girders, or suspension cables to provide safe passage over rivers, canals, or steep ravines in remote areas. Workers focus on anchoring deep, stable foundations and installing high-tension handrails to ensure the structural integrity and safety of the crossing during heavy monsoon flows or flash floods. Once completed, the bridge provides essential year-round connectivity for school children and farmers, ensuring uninterrupted access to markets and healthcare facilities for the local community.

Thematic Domain: Domain II: Core Rural Infrastructure (Rural Amenities)
content: This work involves constructing a durable, all-weather transport surface by laying multiple compacted layers of stone aggregates bonded with hot-mixed bituminous binder. Workers focus on preparing a stable sub-grade and base course before applying the tack coat and a dense bituminous macadam top layer to ensure a smooth, water-resistant finish. Once completed, the road provides a reliable connection for heavy vehicular traffic, significantly reducing travel time and improving market access for rural and semi-urban communities.

Thematic Domain: Domain II: Core Rural Infrastructure (Rural Amenities)
content: This work involves constructing a rigid, high-durability transport surface by laying a thick slab of reinforced or plain cement concrete over a compacted granular sub-base. Workers focus on precise formwork setting, the placement of dowel bars for load transfer, and systematic curing to ensure the pavement reaches maximum compressive strength without cracking. Once completed, the road provides a maintenance-free, all-weather path capable of supporting heavy axle loads, significantly improving long-term connectivity and hygiene in residential and rural areas.

Thematic Domain: Domain II: Core Rural Infrastructure (Rural Amenities)
Work Name: Construction of Interlocking Paver Block Road
content: This work involves constructing a flexible, heavy-duty transport surface by fitting together high-strength precast concrete blocks over a compacted sand bedding and stone aggregate base. Workers focus on precise edge restraint installation and vibration-compacting the blocks to ensure the joints are tightly filled with fine sand for structural interlocking. Once completed, the road provides a durable, aesthetically pleasing, and easy-to-repair surface that allows for natural water percolation and immediate traffic use.

Thematic Domain: Domain II: Core Rural Infrastructure (Rural Amenities)
content: This work involves constructing a traditional, durable rural path by laying high-quality bricks in a vertical or on-edge zigzag pattern over a compacted earth and sand base. Workers focus on creating a slight central camber and installing sturdy brick or stone side edgings to ensure efficient surface water drainage and prevent lateral shifting of the pavement. Once completed, the road provides a cost-effective, all-weather track that significantly improves mud-free connectivity for pedestrians, bicycles, and light farm vehicles in village settlements.

Thematic Domain: Domain II: Core Rural Infrastructure (Rural Amenities)
content: This work involves constructing a durable, water-bound macadam surface by laying successive layers of crushed stone aggregates and screening material compacted with water and a binding agent. Workers focus on achieving a precise camber and spreading stone dust or moorum to fill all interstitial voids, ensuring a dense, interlocking structural layer. Once completed, the road provides a stable, all-weather base for rural traffic or acts as a high-quality foundation for future bitumen or concrete surfacing.

Once completed, the building serves as a vibrant community hub for immunization, nutrition monitoring, and pre-school learning, significantly improving the health and educational outcomes of rural children.

content: This work involves constructing a secure, reinforced masonry or precast concrete perimeter around public land to prevent encroachment and ensure the safety of institutional assets. Workers focus on excavating stable strip foundations and installing periodic expansion joints and integrated weep holes to maintain structural integrity against soil pressure and moisture. Once completed, the boundary wall provides a clear physical demarcation and a protective barrier for schools, hospitals, or offices, allowing for the organized development of internal campus facilities.

Workers focus on installing integrated laboratory workstations with high-quality granite tops, deep-set ceramic sinks, and a systematic network of gas, water, and electrical points. Thematic Domain: Domain II: Core Rural Infrastructure (Rural Amenities)
Work Name: Construction of Play Ground for Government School
content: This work involves the systematic leveling and clearing of designated school land to create a safe, multi-sport surface for physical education and recreation. Workers focus on excavating for proper sub-surface drainage, laying a compacted morum or grass turf layer, and installing durable sports equipment like goalposts or volleyball nets. Once completed, the playground provides a structured environment for outdoor activities and team sports, significantly improving the physical health, discipline, and overall well-being of the students.

Thematic Domain: Domain II: Core Rural Infrastructure (Rural Amenities)
Work Name: Construction of Toilet for Government School
content: This work involves constructing a high-capacity, hygienic sanitation block with separate reinforced masonry units for boys and girls to ensure privacy and dignity within the school premises. Workers focus on installing durable ceramic squatting plates, continuous water supply lines, and a robust twin-pit or septic tank system for long-term, low-maintenance waste disposal. Once completed, the school toilet provides a safe and clean facility that significantly reduces dropout rates, particularly among girl students, while promoting essential health and hygiene practices.

Once completed, the crematorium serves as a vital civic amenity that ensures a sanitary and respectful environment for grieving families while maintaining the public health standards of the community.

Once completed, the graveyard provides a peaceful, well-demarcated area for traditional burials, ensuring a respectful environment for grieving families while preventing encroachment on community land.

Thematic Domain: Domain II: Core Rural Infrastructure (Rural Amenities)
Work Name: Repair and Maintenance of Storage Structure for Water Supply Project (JJM)
content: This work involves constructing a high-capacity reinforced concrete overhead or ground-level reservoir with specialized water-tight masonry to ensure a continuous and pressurized supply of potable water. Workers focus on excavating deep raft foundations for structural stability and applying multi-layer food-grade epoxy coating to the internal walls to prevent seepage and bacterial growth. Once completed, the storage structure serves as a critical utility hub that balances peak demand and maintains hydraulic pressure, significantly improving the reliability of water distribution for the entire community.

Thematic Domain: Domain II: Core Rural Infrastructure (Rural Amenities)
Work Name: Repair and Maintenance of Distribution Structure Water Supply Project (JJM)
content: This work involves constructing an intricate network of reinforced masonry chambers and high-density polyethylene (HDPE) or Cast Iron (CI) pipelines to ensure the equitable flow of potable water across the community. Workers focus on installing precision-engineered sluice valves, air release valves, and non-return valves within protective brick enclosures to manage hydraulic pressure and prevent pipe bursts. Once completed, the distribution structure serves as the vital final link in the utility chain, significantly improving the reach and consistency of water delivery to individual household connections.

Thematic Domain: Domain II: Core Rural Infrastructure (Rural Amenities)
content: This work involves constructing a high-capacity, multi-user reinforced masonry structure with separate blocks for men and women to provide dignified sanitation in densely populated or public areas. Workers focus on installing durable ceramic squatting plates, a dedicated overhead water tank for continuous flushing, and an integrated stainless steel washbasin area for hand hygiene. Once completed, the complex serves as a vital public utility that eliminates open defecation and significantly improves the overall environmental health and cleanliness of the community.

Thematic Domain: Domain II: Core Rural Infrastructure (Rural Amenities)
content: This work involves constructing a compact, reinforced masonry sanitation unit within a household's premises to provide a private and hygienic space for safe disposal of human waste. Workers focus on installing a durable ceramic squatting plate, a high-quality P-trap to prevent odors, and a twin-pit soakage system for efficient, long-term onsite waste management. Once completed, the individual household latrine ensures the dignity and safety of family members, particularly women and the elderly, while significantly contributing to the achievement of an open defecation-free community.

Thematic Domain: Domain II: Core Rural Infrastructure (Rural Amenities)
content: This work involves constructing a reinforced masonry or pre-cast concrete underground chamber with a permeable base to facilitate the aerobic decomposition of organic waste into nutrient-rich manure. Workers focus on creating a multi-chambered layout with perforated side walls for essential aeration and a secure, removable top cover to prevent the entry of rainwater and pests. Once completed, the compost collection pit serves as a vital decentralized waste management unit, significantly reducing environmental pollution while providing high-quality organic fertilizer for local agricultural use.

Thematic Domain: Domain II: Core Rural Infrastructure (Rural Amenities)
content: This work involves constructing a robust reinforced concrete framed structure with an expansive, high-clearance masonry layout to facilitate the systematic sorting of dry and wet municipal waste. Workers focus on creating dedicated concrete bays for different recyclable categories, integrated wash-down areas with proper slope for drainage, and a secure, well-ventilated storage space for processed materials. Once completed, the segregation shed serves as a critical recovery facility that prevents landfill overflow and significantly improves the efficiency of community-wide waste management and recycling programs.

Thematic Domain: Domain II: Core Rural Infrastructure (Rural Amenities)
content: This work involves constructing a high-capacity underground filtration chamber with perforated masonry walls to provide a localized and sustainable solution for the safe disposal of greywater. Workers focus on excavating a deep vertical shaft filled with graded layers of coarse aggregate, charcoal, and sand to facilitate the natural biological and physical purification of wastewater. Once completed, the soak pit serves as a vital decentralized drainage unit that prevents surface waterlogging and mosquito breeding, significantly recharging the local groundwater table.

Thematic Domain: Domain II: Core Rural Infrastructure (Rural Amenities)
content: This work involves constructing a shallow, linear reinforced masonry or stone-lined trench with a permeable base to facilitate the systematic diversion and filtration of domestic greywater. Workers focus on creating a precise longitudinal gradient for gravity flow, complemented by a multi-layer filling of graded brickbats and coarse aggregates to maximize sub-surface absorption. Once completed, the soakage channel serves as a vital decentralized drainage utility that prevents stagnant water accumulation and soil erosion, significantly enhancing the overall sanitation and groundwater recharge of the locality.

Thematic Domain: Domain II: Core Rural Infrastructure (Rural Amenities)
content: This work involves constructing a reinforced masonry or pre-cast concrete underground junction box with a smooth internal cement plaster finish to facilitate the systematic collection and diversion of household greywater. Workers focus on creating a precise benching at the base to ensure a self-cleansing velocity and installing a heavy-duty airtight cover to prevent the escape of foul odors and the entry of debris. Once completed, the liquid waste chamber serves as a critical distribution node that connects individual household drains to the main soakage system, significantly reducing open waterlogging and maintaining the overall hygiene of the street.

Thematic Domain: Domain II: Core Rural Infrastructure (Rural Amenities)
content: This work involves constructing a reinforced concrete or masonry underground digester tank with an airtight dome to facilitate the anaerobic decomposition of organic waste into clean fuel. Workers focus on installing a precise inlet pipe for cow dung slurry, a central fermentation chamber for gas production, and a dedicated outlet for nutrient-rich liquid manure. Once completed, the biogas plant serves as a sustainable energy hub that provides a smoke-free cooking solution and high-quality organic fertilizer, significantly reducing the carbon footprint and fuel expenses of rural households.

Thematic Domain: Domain II: Core Rural Infrastructure (Rural Amenities)
content: This work involves installing a self-contained, pole-mounted photovoltaic system with a reinforced concrete foundation to provide reliable and eco-friendly outdoor illumination. Workers focus on mounting high-efficiency monocrystalline solar panels, a long-life lithium ferro-phosphate (LiFePO4) battery, and a weather-resistant LED luminaire with an automated dusk-to-dawn sensor. Once completed, the solar street light serves as a sustainable security utility that enhances public safety and visibility at night without any recurring electricity costs or external wiring.

Thematic Domain: Domain II: Core Rural Infrastructure (Rural Amenities)
content: This work involves constructing a reinforced concrete framed passenger shelter with durable masonry seating and non-slip flooring to provide a comfortable waiting area for rural commuters. Workers focus on erecting a weather-resistant sloping roof for rainwater runoff, installing clear signage, and creating a paved bay for safe bus docking and passenger boarding. Once completed, the rural bus stand serves as a vital transportation hub that protects villagers from extreme weather, significantly improving the connectivity and economic mobility of the local population.

Once completed, the threshing yard serves as a vital post-harvest utility that provides a clean, mud-free area for farmers, significantly reducing grain breakage and contamination.

Work Name: Construction of Bio-fertilizer and Organic Manure Units
content: This work involves constructing a series of reinforced masonry pits and a shaded processing area with a durable concrete floor to facilitate the natural decomposition of agricultural and animal waste. Workers focus on building brick-lined vermicompost beds, installing proper drainage for liquid nutrients, and erecting a weather-resistant roof to maintain the moisture and temperature required for organic production. Once completed, the bio-fertilizer unit serves as a vital sustainable utility that provides farmers with low-cost, high-quality organic manure, significantly improving soil health and reducing dependence on expensive chemical fertilizers.

Work Name: Construction of Vertical Greywater Treatment Unit
content: This work involves constructing a series of reinforced masonry or plastic filter towers filled with graded layers of gravel, sand, and charcoal to naturally purify wastewater from village households. Workers focus on installing an inlet pipe system for domestic runoff and a collection pit at the base to capture treated water for reuse in kitchen gardens or groundwater recharge. Once completed, the vertical greywater treatment unit serves as a vital sanitation utility that prevents stagnant water pooling in streets, significantly improving village hygiene and water conservation.

Work Name: Construction of Horizontal Greywater Treatment Unit
content: This work involves constructing a series of shallow, interconnected masonry chambers filled with graded stone aggregates and sand to naturally filter household wastewater through horizontal flow. Workers focus on building brick-lined sedimentation tanks and filter beds with a slight slope to ensure steady water movement and effective removal of impurities. Once completed, the horizontal greywater treatment unit serves as a vital sanitation system that prevents waterlogging and provides clean, recycled water for local irrigation and groundwater recharge.

Work Name: Construction of Mini Flour Mill Processing Unit
content: This work involves constructing a reinforced masonry or RCC framed building with a sturdy, vibration-resistant concrete floor to house high-speed mechanical grinding and processing machinery. Workers focus on installing heavy-duty electrical connections, well-ventilated windows for dust control, and secure storage bays for both raw grain and finished flour. Once completed, the mini flour mill processing unit serves as a vital local utility that provides convenient milling services and value-addition opportunities, significantly improving the income of rural entrepreneurs and saving travel time for villagers.

This work involves constructing a reinforced masonry or RCC framed building with dedicated sections for steaming, deshelling, and drying raw cashew nuts. Workers focus on installing a heavy-duty heat-resistant floor, proper ventilation for smoke and steam, and secure storage areas for both raw and processed kernels. Once completed, the cashew processing unit serves as a vital value-addition hub that enables local farmers to sell processed nuts instead of raw ones, significantly increasing their profit and creating local jobs.

Work Name: Construction of Oil Seed Processing Unit
content: This work involves constructing a reinforced masonry or RCC framed building with a vibration-resistant concrete floor to house mechanical oil expellers and filtration equipment. Workers focus on installing heavy-duty electrical points, well-ventilated windows for heat control, and secure storage areas for both raw oilseeds and finished oil containers. Once completed, the oil seed processing unit serves as a vital value-addition hub that allows farmers to produce and sell pure local oil, significantly increasing their income and providing fresh oil to the village.

Work Name: Construction of Integrated Agro Processing Unit (Cleaning/Grading/Packaging)
content: This work involves constructing a reinforced masonry or RCC framed building with a large open-plan hall and heavy-duty concrete flooring to house mechanical cleaners, graders, and packing machines. Workers focus on installing high-capacity electrical points, well-ventilated windows for dust control, and secure bays for storing raw and finished agricultural goods. Once completed, the integrated agro processing unit serves as a vital value-addition hub that enables farmers to sort and package their produce locally, significantly increasing their market value and reducing transport costs.

Work Name: Construction of Forest Produce Processing Unit
content: This work involves constructing a reinforced masonry or RCC framed building with dedicated sections for cleaning, drying, and primary processing of non-timber forest products like mahua, honey, or medicinal plants. Workers focus on installing durable cement flooring, high-ventilation windows for moisture control, and secure, pest-proof storage rooms for delicate forest goods. Once completed, the forest produce processing unit serves as a vital value-addition hub that empowers tribal and rural collectors to process their harvest locally, significantly increasing their income and reducing seasonal wastage.

This work involves constructing a reinforced masonry or RCC framed building with a large, well-lit hall and sturdy concrete flooring to house traditional handlooms and yarn-winding equipment. Workers focus on installing high-ventilation windows for natural light, secure storage for silk or cotton threads, and dedicated spaces for dyeing and drying finished fabrics. Once completed, the handloom processing unit serves as a vital craft hub that enables local weavers to work together efficiently, significantly increasing their collective output and preserving traditional rural livelihoods.

Work Name: Construction of Hot Press Biodegradable Processing Unit (Plates/Bowls)
content: This work involves constructing a reinforced masonry or RCC building with a heat-resistant concrete floor to house mechanical hot-press machines for making plates and bowls from fallen leaves or agricultural waste. Workers focus on installing heavy-duty electrical points, well-ventilated drying racks for finished products, and secure storage bays for raw materials and molds. Once completed, the hot press biodegradable processing unit serves as a vital eco-friendly hub that turns waste into profit, significantly increasing the income of rural SHGs and providing a green alternative to plastic.

Work Name: Construction of Bamboo Craft Processing Unit
content: This work involves constructing a reinforced masonry or RCC framed building with a large, open-plan hall and sturdy concrete flooring to house specialized tools for cutting, splitting, and weaving bamboo. Workers focus on installing high-ventilation windows for drying raw bamboo, secure storage bays for finished handicrafts, and dedicated chemical treatment tanks to prevent pest infestation. Once completed, the bamboo craft processing unit serves as a vital value-addition hub that enables rural artisans to create high-quality products locally, significantly increasing their income and preserving traditional craftsmanship.

This work involves constructing a versatile reinforced masonry or RCC framed building with a durable concrete floor and high-capacity electrical points to accommodate various small-scale rural industries. Workers focus on installing large, well-ventilated windows for a healthy workspace, secure lockable storage for raw materials, and open-plan halls for flexible machinery installation. Once completed, this processing unit serves as a vital multi-purpose hub that enables the village to start new local businesses, significantly increasing employment and providing a dedicated space for value-addition activities.

This work involves constructing a reinforced masonry or RCC framed building with a large, heavy-duty concrete floor to house machinery for sorting, shredding, and processing village plastic and metal waste. Workers focus on installing elevated sorting belts, high-capacity electrical points for recycling machines, and secure bays for storing raw scrap and finished recycled pellets. Once completed, the recycling plant serves as a vital environmental hub that turns village waste into reusable raw materials, significantly increasing local cleanliness and providing a new source of green income.

This work involves constructing a series of three interconnected reinforced masonry pits with a durable concrete base to facilitate a high-speed, 18-day aerobic composting process. Workers focus on building brick-lined walls with adequate aeration gaps, installing a shaded roof to maintain moisture, and creating a smooth floor for easy turning of organic waste. Once completed, the Berkeley compost pit serves as a vital rapid-production utility that provides farmers with nutrient-rich manure in a very short time, significantly increasing crop yields and soil fertility.

This work involves constructing a reinforced masonry or brick-lined pit with a durable concrete base to facilitate the natural decomposition of agricultural and household organic waste. Workers focus on building sturdy side walls with proper aeration gaps and a sloped floor to manage moisture and ensure easy turning of the compost. Once completed, the compost pit serves as a vital local utility that converts waste into high-quality organic manure, significantly improving soil health and reducing the need for chemical fertilizers.

This work involves constructing a rectangular reinforced masonry tank with specific honeycomb brickwork to ensure maximum aeration for the aerobic decomposition of organic matter. Workers focus on building perforated side walls and a smooth floor to allow air circulation while layering agricultural waste, cow dung, and dry soil for high-quality manure production. Once completed, the NADEP compost pit serves as a vital large-scale utility that produces nutrient-rich fertilizer in bulk, significantly improving long-term soil fertility and crop health.

This work involves constructing a series of shallow, reinforced masonry or brick-lined beds with a durable concrete base to provide a controlled environment for earthworms to process organic waste. Workers focus on building shaded walls with proper drainage outlets and a protective roof to maintain the ideal moisture and cool temperature needed for the worms to thrive. Once completed, the vermi compost structure serves as a vital high-nutrient fertilizer unit that produces premium organic manure, significantly improving soil quality and crop yields for local farmers.

This work involves constructing a reinforced masonry or RCC framed structure with a durable, anti-skid concrete floor and a sloped roof to provide safe housing for livestock. Workers focus on building integrated mangers for fodder, a dedicated drainage channel for urine and dung, and a secure tethering system to ensure animal hygiene and comfort. Once completed, the cattle shelter serves as a vital dairy utility that protects animals from extreme weather, significantly improving milk yield and the overall health of the village livestock.

This work involves constructing a reinforced masonry or concrete water tank with smooth internal plastering to provide a clean and constant drinking source for village livestock. Workers focus on building sturdy side walls at an accessible height and a sloped floor for easy cleaning, alongside a dedicated inlet for fresh water and a drainage outlet. Once completed, the cattle trough serves as a vital community utility that ensures animals stay hydrated and healthy throughout the day, significantly reducing the labor of manual watering for farmers.

This work involves preparing a dedicated plot of land with reinforced bunding and an efficient irrigation channel to grow high-protein green fodder for village livestock. Workers focus on leveling the soil, applying organic manure for rapid growth, and setting up a sustainable harvesting cycle to ensure a year-round supply of fresh feed. Once completed, the fodder cultivation unit serves as a vital dairy support system that reduces the cost of animal rearing, significantly increasing milk production and the health of the cattle.

This work involves constructing a reinforced masonry or bamboo-framed structure with a raised slatted floor and a sloped roof to provide a dry, ventilated living space for goats. Workers focus on building dedicated feeding mangers, a secure perimeter fence, and a sloped concrete base for easy cleaning and waste collection. Once completed, the goat shelter serves as a vital livestock utility that protects the herd from predators and damp ground, significantly reducing disease and increasing the income of small-scale farmers.

This work involves constructing a reinforced masonry or RCC framed building with a hygienic, easy-to-clean concrete floor and a cool, insulated roof to house milk collection and storage equipment. Workers focus on installing stainless steel cooling tanks, dedicated testing counters for quality checks, and a reliable electrical system for refrigeration and bulk chilling. Once completed, the milk production centre serves as a vital community hub that enables local farmers to safely store and sell high-quality milk, significantly increasing their daily income and reducing wastage.

Workers focus on building individual farrowing pens, integrated feeding and watering troughs, and a dedicated drainage system for efficient waste removal. Once completed, the piggery shed serves as a vital livestock utility that protects the animals from disease and extreme weather, significantly increasing the growth rate and profit for rural farmers.

This work involves constructing a reinforced masonry or bamboo-framed structure with a high-ventilation roof and a secure wire-mesh perimeter to house chickens in a safe environment. Workers focus on building a smooth concrete floor for easy cleaning, dedicated feeding and watering stations, and elevated nesting boxes for egg collection. Once completed, the poultry shelter serves as a vital livestock utility that protects the birds from predators and disease, significantly increasing egg and meat production for rural families.

Work Name: Construction of Aquaculture Structure for Shrimp Farming
content: This work involves excavating a series of specialized ponds with reinforced earthen bunds and a plastic or concrete lining to maintain high water quality for shrimp growth. Workers focus on installing water intake and drainage systems, aeration paddle wheels for oxygen supply, and secure perimeter fencing to protect the crop. Once completed, the aquaculture structure serves as a vital high-value production hub that enables rural farmers to cultivate shrimp for export, significantly increasing their seasonal profits and village trade.

Work Name: Construction of Aquaculture Structure for Fish Farming
content: This work involves excavating deep, reinforced earthen ponds with a durable clay or plastic lining and high-strength bunds to hold water for breeding and growing fish. Workers focus on constructing efficient water inlet and outlet channels, internal slopes for easy harvesting, and secure perimeter fencing to protect the stock from predators. Once completed, the aquaculture structure serves as a vital water-based farm that provides a steady supply of fresh fish, significantly increasing the village’s food security and daily income.

Work Name: Construction of Aquaculture Structure for Crab Farming
content: This work involves excavating specialized mud-bottom ponds with high, reinforced earthen bunds and secure perimeter fencing to prevent crabs from escaping or being taken by predators. Workers focus on constructing hidden earthen holes or PVC pipe shelters for crab nesting, alongside efficient water inlet and outlet gates for regular tidal or fresh water exchange. Once completed, the aquaculture structure serves as a vital high-value production unit that enables rural families to harvest crabs for premium markets, significantly increasing their seasonal earnings.

This work involves constructing a large, elevated concrete platform with a smooth, sun-exposed surface to provide a hygienic space for drying fish. Workers focus on building a sloped floor for efficient water drainage, a low perimeter wall to keep out dust, and installing high-tensile drying racks or nets. Once completed, the fish drying yard serves as a vital processing hub that prevents catch spoilage, significantly increasing the market value of the fish and the income of coastal fishing families.

This work involves excavating a large, deep pond with reinforced earthen bunds and a durable clay or plastic lining to hold water for breeding and harvesting fish. Workers focus on building efficient inlet and outlet channels for water exchange, sloped internal walls for easy netting, and secure fencing to protect the stock. Once completed, the fishery pond serves as a vital community resource that provides a steady supply of fresh fish, significantly increasing the village’s food security and local trade income.

This work involves setting up a local unit for manufacturing essential construction items like fly-ash bricks, interlocking blocks, and reinforced concrete rings. Workers focus on preparing raw material mixes, using manual or semi-automatic molding machines, and curing the finished products in shaded drying yards. Once operational, the building material production unit serves as a vital village industry that provides low-cost, high-quality supplies for local infrastructure, significantly increasing rural employment and self-reliance.

This work involves preparing a dedicated, shaded plot of land with fine-tilled soil and raised beds to grow healthy young saplings from seeds. Workers focus on installing a bamboo or net-covered framework for protection, a regular watering system, and organic manuring for fast growth. Once completed, the nursery serves as a vital green utility that provides the village with affordable fruit, timber, and medicinal plants, significantly increasing local forest cover and farmer income.

This work involves constructing a high-strength, reinforced concrete building on raised stilts with a wind-resistant roof to provide a safe refuge during extreme storms. Workers focus on building thick masonry walls, emergency ramps for accessibility, and installing heavy-duty shutters and ventilation systems for safety. Once completed, the cyclone shelter serves as a vital life-saving utility that protects hundreds of villagers and their essential belongings, significantly reducing casualties during natural disasters.

This work involves excavating and compacting soil to build high, wide earthen walls along riverbanks or low-lying areas to prevent floodwaters from entering village fields and homes. Workers focus on creating a stable slope, reinforcing the structure with stone pitching or grass turfing, and ensuring proper height to withstand heavy monsoon flow. Once completed, the embankment serves as a vital protective barrier that saves crops from being washed away, significantly increasing the safety and seasonal income of rural families.

This work involves constructing a heavy earthen and stone structure that extends from the riverbank into the water to deflect the strong current away from the village land. Workers focus on excavating deep foundations, compacting soil layers, and adding heavy stone boulders to prevent the river from eating away the fertile soil. Once completed, the earthen spur serves as a vital protective shield that stops soil erosion, significantly saving the village's agricultural fields and homes from being destroyed by the river.

This work involves constructing a heavy-duty permeable structure using large stones packed tightly inside high-strength wire mesh cages to deflect river currents. Workers focus on layering these stone-filled crates from the riverbank into the water to break the force of waves and prevent the soil from washing away. Once completed, the gabion spur serves as a vital protective barrier that stops land erosion, significantly saving the village's fertile agricultural fields and nearby houses from river damage.

This work involves constructing a heavy, wedge-shaped structure using large boulders and stones packed tightly together to divert the forceful flow of a river away from the banks. Workers focus on laying a deep foundation of heavy stones and building a slanted wall that juts into the water to break the current and prevent soil erosion. Once completed, the stone spur serves as a vital protective barrier that stops the river from eating into agricultural land, significantly saving the village's fertile fields and homes.

Once completed, the storm water drain serves as a vital sanitation utility that keeps the village streets dry and hygienic, significantly reducing the risk of waterborne diseases and property damage during heavy rains.

Once completed, the flood diversion channel serves as a vital safety utility that prevents the village from being submerged, significantly protecting homes and standing crops during heavy monsoons.

Once completed, the flood protection wall serves as a vital safety shield that keeps homes and cattle sheds dry, significantly reducing the loss of property and life during the peak monsoon season.

This work involves building a solid, low-height wall using stones or bricks and cement mortar across a sloped field to stop soil erosion and store rainwater. Workers focus on digging a firm foundation and layering the masonry to create a strong barrier that slows down water runoff and allows it to soak into the earth. Once completed, the masonry bund serves as a vital land improvement structure that keeps the fertile topsoil in place, significantly increasing the moisture and productivity of the farmer's field.

This work involves building a thick, stepped wall using compacted layers of local soil and stone to support steep slopes and prevent landslides. Workers focus on digging a wide base, packing the earth tightly in levels, and adding a grass cover or stone casing to keep the structure firm against heavy rain. Once completed, the earthen retaining wall serves as a vital safety barrier that stops soil from sliding into homes or roads, significantly protecting village property and pathways.

Workers focus on digging a firm foundation and layering the stone-filled blocks to prevent hillsides or riverbanks from sliding and washing away during heavy rains. Once completed, the stone or gabion retaining wall serves as a vital safety barrier that protects village roads and houses from landslides, significantly increasing the stability of the local land.

Once completed, the masonry retaining wall serves as a vital safety barrier that protects village roads and houses from landslides, significantly increasing the stability of the local hilly or uneven land.

Once completed, the RCC retaining wall serves as a vital safety structure that prevents major landslides and soil collapses, significantly protecting village roads and houses in hilly areas.

Work Name: Construction of 3/5 Pond for Grey Water Management
content: This work involves digging a series of three to five small interconnected pits or ponds to naturally filter and treat dirty wastewater coming from village households. Workers focus on layering the ponds with stones, sand, and charcoal while planting specific reeds to absorb impurities and clear the water of grease and soap. Once completed, the 3/5 pond system serves as a vital sanitation utility that prevents smelly water from pooling in streets, significantly reducing mosquito breeding and keeping the village environment clean.

This work involves building a permanent, lined channel using stones or bricks and cement mortar to carry dirty household water away from homes to a soak pit. Workers focus on creating a smooth, sloped floor and solid side walls to ensure water flows easily without leaking into the ground or causing bad smells. Once completed, the masonry greywater drain serves as a vital sanitation utility that keeps village lanes dry and mud-free, significantly reducing the breeding of mosquitoes and the spread of diseases.

This work involves digging a large, shallow pond designed to treat village sewage and wastewater using sunlight, bacteria, and natural air. Workers focus on excavating a flat-bottomed basin with strong earthen side walls and a steady inlet to allow dirty water to sit and clean itself over several days. Once completed, the stabilisation pond serves as a vital sanitation utility that removes harmful germs from wastewater, significantly reducing water pollution and making the outflow safe for irrigating local fields.

This work involves repairing damaged village paths by filling potholes with local soil and gravel to make them level and smooth again. Workers focus on clearing bushes from the sides, improving the road's slope for rainwater drainage, and compacting the surface to ensure it stays firm for carts and vehicles. Once completed, the restoration of rural roads serves as a vital transport link that connects the village to markets and schools, significantly saving travel time and reducing vehicle wear and tear.

Work Name: Post-Disaster Restoration of Other Community Assests
content: This work involves repairing and strengthening shared village structures like community halls, grain storage sheds, and cattle shelters to make them functional again. Workers focus on fixing cracked walls, replacing damaged roofs, and leveling the floors to ensure these spaces are safe for public gatherings and local use. Once completed, the restoration of community assets serves as a vital resource for the whole village, significantly improving the quality of common living and storage spaces for everyone.

Work Name: Post-Disaster Restoration of Community Building Assests
content: This work involves repairing and strengthening shared village structures like community halls, school rooms, and health centers to make them safe and usable again. Workers focus on fixing cracked walls, replacing broken roof tiles, and leveling floors to ensure these spaces can host village meetings and local functions. Once completed, the restoration of community building assets serves as a vital resource for the whole village, significantly improving the quality of common spaces for gathering and education.

This work involves planting multiple rows of tall trees and thick shrubs along the edges of village fields to act as a natural wall against strong winds. Workers focus on digging pits, choosing hardy local species, and installing fencing to protect the young saplings from grazing cattle during their early growth. Once matured, the shelterbelt plantation serves as a vital environmental shield that stops soil erosion and protects standing crops from wind damage, significantly increasing the long-term fertility of the land.

This work involves digging deep, wide V-shaped ditches along the boundaries of village forests or community lands to prevent wild animals and stray cattle from entering and damaging standing crops. Workers focus on excavating the earth to a specific depth that animals cannot cross, while piling the dug-out soil on the inner side to create an additional earthen mound barrier. Once completed, the animal protection trench serves as a vital natural fence that keeps livestock and wildlife away from farms, significantly reducing crop loss and conflict between humans and animals.

This work involves clearing wide strips of land and planting rows of fire-resistant trees and green shrubs to act as a natural barrier against spreading forest or field fires. Workers focus on removing dry grass and debris between these rows to ensure that a fire cannot jump from one area of the village to another. Once grown, the raising of fire break hedges serves as a vital safety belt that stops small fires from becoming large disasters, significantly protecting homes, cattle, and standing crops.

This work involves clearing a wide, continuous strip of land within or around the forest by removing all dry grass, bushes, and fallen leaves to stop the spread of fire. Workers focus on digging out flammable material and keeping the ground bare so that a ground fire cannot cross from one section of the forest to another. Once completed, the forest fire line serves as a vital safety corridor that protects village timber, medicinal plants, and nearby grazing lands from being destroyed by sudden summer fires.

This work involves planting fast-growing, local tree species and thick shrubs on the outskirts of the village to provide a dedicated source of firewood for households. Workers focus on digging pits, preparing the soil, and installing fencing to ensure the young saplings grow into a dense green belt that is easily accessible to the community. Once matured, the raising of a fuel buffer zone serves as a vital energy resource that reduces the need to travel deep into natural forests, significantly saving time for women and protecting the village's natural environment.
